snippet: A century after the sinking of the Titanic, new research argues that record tides and ocean mirages may help explain a disaster long associated with human ineptitude.
abstract: Scholars and scientists are debating latest theories about the sinking of the Titanic as the centennial of the event approaches; researchers at Texas State University contend that a tidal anomaly may help explain why the ship encountered such high levels of ice; second theory, put forth by a Titanic historian from Britain, suggests that an unusual type of mirage may have prevented lookouts from spotting the fatal iceberg.
lead_paragraph: A century after the sinking of the Titanic, new research argues that record tides and ocean mirages may help explain a disaster long associated with human ineptitude.

headline.seo: A New Look at Nature’s Role in the Titanic’s Sinking
headline.main: The Iceberg Was Only Part of It
